column54: HKFP is governed by a public code of ethics. Best of 2021 Original features: Our features in 2021 documented Hong Kong's transformation under the shadow of the Beijing enacted security law. We delved into how counsellors and psychologists grappled with the fear of creeping self censorship in their practice
column55: how booksellers were reported to the national security police during the Hong Kong Book Fair for selling politically sensitive titles
column56: and how one of the city's last remaining independent bookstores shuttered
column57: citing the political environment. We also looked at how the city's filmmakers
column58: publishers and street artists navigated the shifting red lines
column59: and how some Hongkongers are inking messages of resistance onto their own skin. The city's media landscape forever changed last year with the closure of pro democracy newspaper Apple Daily. HKFP was at its newsrooms and printing presses on its last day of operations. We also explored how the city's Beijing backed press are gaining more influence. The year also saw the mass resignations of pro democracy district councillors after new oath requirements were introduced. We documented the final days of one local councillor in office and explored how the exodus of district representatives also left community newspapers struggling. As protest related and national security cases piled up in the city's courts
column60: we spoke with lawyers compiling a protest case database to preserve the city's rule of law
column61: the activists writing letters to detained protesters
column62: and the international lawyers who launched an advice website to inform Hongkongers of their legal rights. We also spoke with a refugee from Vietnam who was stuck behind bars for almost three decades after being convicted of murder as a teenager
column63: and eventually decided to abandon his fight against deportation. Amid the changes of 2021
column64: a wave of Hongkongers left for the UK. HKFP was at the airport when long queues formed as people bid farewell to loved ones. In the UK
column65: we reported on the people helping newly arrived Hongkongers settle in
column66: as well the pro China groups pressuring them. Hong Kong also saw the implementation of a sweeping overhaul of the city's electoral system. HKFP gave extensive coverage on the day of the city's first 'patriots only' legislative election – candidates made urgent appeal to voters while Hong Kong saw the lowest turnout rate ever. Following a 48 hour purge of Tiananmen Massacre monuments from university campuses over Christmas
column69: as well as artists behind the statues about what the removals meant for Hong Kong's efforts to commemorate those who died in the military crackdown of student led demonstrations over 32 years ago. Our team visited local businesses at risk of forced closure after government led redevelopments in Fo Tan and Kwun Tong. Elsewhere
column70: we spoke with the owners of Hong Kong's remaining iconic Dai Pai Dongs facing eviction from their community
column71: and the elderly villager fighting to save his home from developers in the New Territories. We also reported on the opening of the newly revamped historic Central Market and the long awaited M+ museum. Covid 19 restrictions continued to disrupt Hongkongers' daily lives last year. We examined government statistics to question whether the city's severe quarantine measures were really necessary
column72: how even vaccinated people were forced into quarantine centres
column73: how foreign domestic workers faced more challenging working conditions during the pandemic

column83: and published a probe into one of the city's oldest sporting associations. column86: and the task force fighting against dog poisonings. Last year

column101: and we continued our 'shifting narratives' series on how the city's leaders' attitude towards the Tiananmen Massacre and the traditional mass pro democracy marches on July 1 evolved over recent years. We wrote explainers on major political developments

column105: analysing what it all meant for the city's future. column106: and who the approved candidates were in the city's first legislative poll following the sweeping overhaul. Our team also wrote practical guides informing our readers how to sign up for the government's electronic stimulus vouchers
column107: how to enter lucky draws for the fully vaccinated

column1: https://hongkongfp.com/2022/11/15/autistic-hong-kong-man-sentenced-to-12-months-in-jail-for-sedition-and-inciting-others-to-take-part-in-illegal-assembly/;2022-11-15 18:29:00+08:00; Autistic Hong Kong man sentenced to 12 months in jail for sedition and inciting others to take part in illegal assembly; Hong Kong Free Press HKFP Hong Kong news – Independent
column2: impartial
column3: non profit An autistic man convicted under Hong Kong's colonial era sedition law has been sentenced to 12 months in prison after pleading guilty to three counts of doing acts with seditious intent and one count of inciting others to take part in an illegal assembly. Chan Tai sum
column5: appeared in front of Judge Stanley Chan
column6: one of the city's handpicked national security judges
column7: at the District Court on Tuesday. The 23 year old pleaded guilty to the four offences in last month
column8: after Kwok Wai kin
column9: another national security judge
column10: ruled against Chan's barrister's application to move the trial to the High Court. According to the prosecution
column11: Chan incited people to gather in Causeway Bay and Yau Tsim Mong on Christmas Eve by publishing posts on two telegram groups on December 13 last year. Chan was also said to have published multiple 'seditious' posts on online forum LIHKG between August 19 and December 8 last year
column12: including posts where he described the central and Hong Kong governments as 'bandits
column13: ' and encouraged people to overturn the 'tyranny' of the Communist Party of China. Chan has autism
column14: and had difficulty in face to face communication with other people
column15: his barrister Steven Kwan said during mitigation. Kwan also said that the 23 year old was bullied during his time in remand. The barrister said that Chan made those posts as an attempt to gain recognition from other people online
column16: as he could not do so in real life. Chan did not give much thought to the posts before publishing them
column17: Kwan added. Citing a Court of Appeal case
column18: Kwan said that the court should take Chan's mental disorder into account when considering his sentence
column19: as the defendant was influenced by his condition when committing the offence. Mitigation letters
column20: including one written by Chan himself
column21: were also submitted to the court. Chan was remorseful
column22: Kwan said
column23: which was shown not only in his mitigation letter but also in his decision to plead guilty at an early stage. Handing down his judgement on Tuesday afternoon
column24: the judge said Chan committed the offence after the implementation of the national security law
column25: which showed that he viewed the Beijing imposed legislation as a 'paper tiger.' 'The defendant having autism is not an excuse to say that he does not understand the legal consequences
column26: ' Stanley Chan wrote. The sedition law
column27: while falling under the Crimes Ordinance
column28: shares the same bail threshold as the national security law
column29: and cases under the colonial era legislation are also heard by handpicked national security judges. Kwan's mitigation that the defendant acted alone was also refuted by the judge
column30: who said that the argument was a 'generalisation.' Judge Chan ruled that the defendant could have incited 'lone wolves' who could harm themselves and others
column31: and thus warranted a heavy punishment to act as a deterrent. Judge Chan also said he omitted all 'inappropriate wordings and phrases' in his judgement to avoid publishing illegal messages or insulting words for the defendant again. The judge sentenced the 23 year old to 10 months in prison for the incitement charge
column32: and eight months in prison for the sedition charges after applying a one third deduction for pleading guilty. After ruling that four months of the prison term for the sedition charges could be served consecutively with the 10 month sentence
column33: Chan was sentenced to 12 months in prison
column34: with the judge deducting another two months in light of the defendant's background and mental disorder. column4: non profit Hong Kong's largest non hospital medical services provider EC Healthcare shared clients' personal data among various brands owned by the group
column5: the official privacy watchdog has found. The Office of the Privacy Commissioner for Personal Data (PCPD) released the results of an investigation into EC Healthcare at a press conference on Monday
column6: revealing that the group had shared clients' full names
column7: transaction details and medical records among its subsidiaries via an integrated customer service system. The system in question was used by 28 of the 39 brands owned by the group
column8: involving 1.08 million clients. EC Healthcare did not inform all clients or get their consent before disclosing and transferring their personal information
column9: the PCPD office found. The exact number of clients affected was not identified. The customer information in question was made available to EC Healthcare's customer service
column10: cashier
column11: hotline centre and front desk staff via the system. The Privacy Commissioner for Personal Data Ada Chung said the firm's practices were 'disappointing both from the perspective of compliance with legal requirements or that of respecting clients' wills.' She said EC Healthcare contravened the requirements under the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance. An enforcement order was issued to the group requesting it to stop sharing customer data without consent
column12: as well as provide training and establish clear boundaries for staff who can access the data. According to Chung
column13: the company has to meet the requirements of the enforcement order within three months or risk a maximum jail term of two years and HK$50
column14: 000 fine
column15: with HK$1
column16: 000 additional for each day overdue. Chung said that the current punishments were considered 'insufficient.' 'We will work with the government and review the entire privacy ordinance
column17: including its penalties
column18: ' she added
column19: without giving a timeframe. The investigation was launched after two separate complaints were filed to PCPD last June and July
column20: respectively. In both cases
column21: brands under EC Healthcare obtained the full names of the complainant or their family members without the customers providing such data. The clients involved had each provided their information to either Primecare Paediatric Wellness Centre or New York Medical Group. The privacy watchdog found that when the two brands were later acquired by EC Healthcare
column22: some of their client data was shared among different companies under the new parent firm using the integrated system. EC Healthcare told the watchdog that the system was set up to 'provide one stop medical and healthcare services
column23: improve the quality of customer services
column24: and make answering client enquiries and handling complaints more convenient for frontline staff.' However
column25: it said that clients' personal data from other companies was not necessary for the individual operation of the brands involved in the complaints cases. Chung said she believed that EC Healthcare's practices were 'not common' in the industry but the watchdog would look into similar large healthcare groups. 'We are monitoring online discussions
column26: news highlights or media reports. If we find there is something irregular in the operation of any particular group  we will initiate enquiries proactively without waiting for any complaints
column27: ' she added. PCPD also released findings from an investigation into Fotomax on Monday. The photo finishing service chain suffered a ransomware attack in October 2021
column28: in which the data of544
column29: 862 registered members and 73
column30: 957 other customers of its online store was maliciously encrypted. The watchdog said the data hack was made possible by 'serious deficiencies.' The company admitted to PCPD that it had learned of a loophole in its firewall in September 2019 but it believed that its existing data security measures were sufficient to fend off related threats and did not install the security patch. Fotomax also delayed the implementation of multi factor authentication as urged by the firewall provider
column31: PCPD found. Chung said the company had contravened the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance as it had not taken all practical steps to ensure the protection of personal data. column5: the government also launched an online booking system pilot scheme for the Twisk Campsite in Tai Lam Country Park to allow advance reservation of camping spots. HKFP explains how to navigate the booking site. Twisk Campsite is located in Tai Lam Country Park near Tai Mo Shan
column6: the highest peak in Hong Kong. You can take Bus 51 (Sheung Tsuen bound) from Nina Tower Bus Terminus in Tsuen Wan and get off at 'Tai Mo Shan Country Park.' From there
column7: it is a five minute walk before you arrive at the campsite entrance. Both Hong Kong residents and non residents are allowed to book a free camping space at the Twisk Campsite. column8: however
column9: as the system asks you to confirm that you are 18 or above on the check in day. The entire Twisk Campsite is divided into five zones with 37 camping units in total – four of them are twin units. A single camping space can accommodate one to four people
column10: while a twin unit holds five to eight people. The government may adjust the maximum number of people allowed per camping unit based on the latest Covid 19 social distancing measures. On the online booking system
column11: you can reserve a camping space for up to two nights
column12: and each applicant can book one unit only. It is possible for campers to extend their stay at the same or a different unit by making another booking for one or two nights after they have checked in. You can stay in the campsite for a maximum of four consecutive nights
column13: subject to the availability of the units. Yes. Once you have selected the dates of your reservation

column15: such asthe shelter
column16: water supply
column17: toilets
column18: refuse collection points and the guard house. Units that are still available will be in green
column19: while the red ones mean they are already taken. Once you have selected the unit you want

column22: Unit 25

column26: as shown on your identification document

column24: visiting perhaps once a week. Muskkan Samtani and Gulshan Dua told HKFP there was no place in Hong Kong that was quite like the Sikh temple. 'During Diwali

column26: referring to one of India's biggest annual festivals
column27: 'there's the food
column28: the prayers
column29: the candles
column30: the huge tables – it's exactly the way we do it back home.' The pair are volunteers with the temple's digital library committee
column31: helping to source books in English and Punjabi – the predominant language spoken by Sikhs – that aim to teach young children about their religion. 'Many children growing up in Hong Kong do not have much exposure to their culture
column32: ' Samtani said. 'They may not understand things like why they need to cover their hair when going to a temple.' According to the temple's website
column33: it is believed that Sikhs first came to Hong Kong around 1840
column34: many of them brought by British colonisers to Hong Kong from India
column35: also part of the British empire
column36: to serve in the police force. The temple was founded in 1901 by the Sikh members of the British Army Regiment in Hong Kong
column37: and was rebuilt after it was bombed by Japanese soldiers in World War II. It holds prayers every morning and evening
column38: with an extra afternoon session on Wednesdays and Saturdays. The temple also offers Punjabi and Sikh literature classes
column39: and there are plans to start Cantonese lessons. Gurdev Singh Ghalib has devoted his days to the temple since retiring six years ago from his chief officer post at the Correctional Services Department. The 61 year old oversaw the temple's redevelopment as convenor of the Building Committee of the Sikh temple. 'This is a focal point for everything
column41: adding that it was a place for 'all ages' from babies to the elderly. In Indian culture
column42: mothers who have just given birth observe a confinement period of 40 days
column43: he said. The custom is similar to the Chinese post partum practice of 'sitting moon.' 'Then they bring the baby to the temple and give them holy water to drink
column44: ' Ghalib said. 'And for those who are retired
column45: they can relax here. They can have a cup of tea and sit in the yard
column46: just to kill time.' Back in the dining hall
column47: Rajbir Singh – who had just attended a morning prayer session upstairs – was finishing up the last of his chapati and masala tea. 'After that
column49: ' he told HKFP as he gestured towards the kitchen
column50: where dozens of volunteers were preparing food
column51: mopping and washing the dishes. Sewa refers to the Sikh concept of providing 'selfless service' at the temple. It comes in the form of volunteering wherever help is needed
column53: fixing appliances or maintenance. The temple employs just 10 staff members
column54: according to Ghalib. In the kitchen
column55: volunteers stirred giant vats of kheer – a type of Indian rice pudding – and cracked open bags of sugar to make masala tea. Others on dishwashing duty dunked trays and utensils into basins of soapy water
column56: their arms lathered in suds. Bally Gill
column58: pointed to a group holding mops and wiping down gas stoves. 'We are the executive cleaning team
column60: we try to do a deep clean.' 'The cooking is important
column61: but we have to make sure that everything is tidy and hygienic too
column63: adding that there could be as many as 20 to 30 cleaners volunteering in the kitchen at any given time. The temple
column65: is more than a place of religious worship. 'It gives us a place for us to get together
column66: to do something of purpose.' Support HKFP    Code of Ethics    Error/typo?    Contact Us  Newsletter   Transparency & Annual Report Support press freedom & help us surpass 1

column1: https://hongkongfp.com/2022/11/06/domestic-workers-who-fall-foul-of-hong-kongs-complex-covid-rules-dispute-hk10000-fines/;2022-11-06 10:00:00+08:00; 'I didn't know': Hong Kong's complex Covid 19 rules see domestic workers fined HK$10
column2: 000 for missing arrival tests; Hong Kong Free Press HKFP Hong Kong news – Independent
column3: impartial
column4: non profit When Anna
column5: a migrant domestic worker
column6: landed in Hong Kong in May
column7: she – like all arrivals to the city – completed a week of hotel quarantine per the Covid 19 rules at the time. Six days later
column8: a friend told her she was required to have taken compulsory Covid 19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests at government centres after leaving her hotel. Anna went to take one immediately
column9: but it was too late. In July
column10: Department of Health officers turned up at her employer's home with a HK$10
column11: 000 fine for missing the tests – an amount more than double the minimum monthly salary for domestic workers. 'I didn't do the tests because I didn't know
column12: ' Anna
column13: who asked to go by a nickname
column14: told HKFP. 'My agency never said anything
column15: and my employer also had no idea.' Anna is among dozens of domestic workers in Hong Kong who have been caught up in the city's byzantine and ever changing measures for overseas arrivals. When she arrived in May
column16: travellers were required to take daily Covid 19 rapid tests and two PCR tests while in hotel quarantine
column17: as well as further PCR tests on the ninth and 12th day of their arrival. For domestic workers
column18: many of whom face a language barrier and – in some cases – are arriving in Hong Kong for the first time
column19: the convoluted Covid 19 rules are only made more complicated
column20: according to unions and NGOs that have been helping workers like Anna to appeal the fines. The Hong Kong Federation of Asian Domestic Workers Unions (FADWU) told HKFP it had helped 34 domestic workers dispute the penalties. After communicating with authorities
column21: the Department of Health rescinded the fines for 33 cases
column22: while one was still being investigated. NGO Mission for Migrant Workers said it was assisting a further 10 domestic workers who had been fined. Authorities had yet to reverse the penalties for most of them
column23: although the fine was scrapped for one who had completed the tests but used inconsistent forms of identification – namely her passport and Hong Kong identity card – when registering. Upon being issued the penalty
column24: the receiver is given three weeks to pay. FADWU told HKFP that many domestic workers who had tried to appeal their fines before approaching the union had not heard back from authorities. Responding to HKFP
column25: the Department of Health said it had issued over 5
column26: 400 fixed penalty notices to 'inbound persons for contravention of compulsory testing notices' from the start of the year until the end of September. In total
column27: 549 fines were dismissed in the same time period. It is unclear how many domestic workers were recipients of those fines. Information about testing requirements is on the government's websites. But the pages are wordy and difficult to navigate
column28: said An An
column29: the organising secretary of FADWU. Authorities also send text messages with reminders of testing dates depending on when an arrival landed
column30: but the language is cumbersome and only in Chinese and English. 'The process is difficult for anyone who travels inbound
column31: let alone migrant workers
column32: ' An An said. Some domestic workers did not receive the messages because they did not have Hong Kong phone numbers. In a pre departure health declaration form
column33: they might have written a mobile number from their native country
column34: while others put down their agency or employer's number
column35: An An added. The declaration form does ask travellers to provide a Hong Kong mobile number or a 'non local mobile number that can receive international roaming SMS' to receive 'important SMS notifications' from the government
column36: but activists say it is difficult for new domestic workers to do so. A domestic worker
column37: who asked to be identified by her nickname Iche
column38: told HKFP she arrived in Hong Kong for the first time in June and quarantined in a hotel for seven days. She did not have a chance to get a Hong Kong sim card because
column40: she had to go straight to quarantine upon landing. 'My agency didn't tell me I needed a Hong Kong number
column41: ' Iche said. 'And the hotel [I quarantined at] didn't remind me about the compulsory testing.' The Department of Health did not respond to HKFP's question about whether it had alternative communication methods for arrivals who could not be contacted. Marites Palma
column42: the founder of activist group Social Justice for Migrant Workers
column43: said some employers had footed the fine for domestic workers and were deducting repayments from their salaries until they have paid it off. Hong Kong's domestic workers earn a minimum monthly salary of HK$4
column45: an amount that was increased by HK$100 last month after being frozen since 2019. The fines
column47: aggravate the debt that many workers are in before they even begin their jobs. 'Many workers coming to Hong Kong already owe a lot of money to the agency because they have to pay a large amount before flying here
column48: ' Palma added. Different parties including workers' employment agencies
column49: the Hong Kong government and the consulate offices of their home countries should do more to ensure that important messages reach domestic workers
column50: unions and NGOs said. 'The agencies have to inform their employers
column51: because otherwise they may not allow the workers to go out and take the compulsory tests
column53: a board member of the Mission for Migrant Workers
column54: said. 'Or they may not understand the [consequence of missing] the tests.' An An of FADWU said the greatest responsibility lies with the government. She suggested that authorities set up information booths at the airport to inform domestic workers of the rules upon landing. 'The government should print out leaflets in minority languages and give them out at the airport
column55: ' she said. Asked how the government was addressing the language barrier faced by domestic workers
column56: the Labour Department told HKFP it posted 'relevant information' on the 'FDH (Foreign Domestic Helpers) Portal
column57: ' a multi lingual section on the department's website that lists general information and updates relating to domestic workers in the city. In a four page reply to FADWU seen by HKFP
column58: the Centre for Health Protection said when hotel quarantine was still required
column59: hotels were tasked with distributing 'reminder notes to inbound travellers upon their discharge from the hotels' stating the dates they must undergo compulsory testing. The centre added that the note was 'translated into nine ethnic minority languages.' FADWU and Palma
column61: said they were not aware of hotels passing out such notes. An An added that the cases FADWU had received were only the tip of the iceberg
column62: saying it was possible that many domestic workers who received the fines did not have success while appealing and were unaware of where to turn for assistance. 'What we ask is for the government to drop all the fines against migrant domestic workers
column63: ' she said. Support HKFP    Code of Ethics    Error/typo?    Contact Us  Newsletter   Transparency & Annual Report Support press freedom & help us surpass 1

column1: https://hongkongfp.com/2022/11/05/lets-talk-about-sex-artist-claudia-chanhoi-on-genitals-shame-and-social-media-censorship/;2022-11-05 10:00:00+08:00; Let's talk about sex: Artist Claudia Chanhoi on genitals
column2: shame and social media censorship; Hong Kong Free Press HKFP Hong Kong news – Independent
column3: impartial
column4: non profit Claudia Chanhoi is used to being censored. After all
column5: she makes Instagram unfriendly art. Her social media pages are peppered with breasts
column6: bums
column7: penises and vaginas
column8: sometimes euphemistically presented
column9: sometimes explicitly so
column10: but always in a highly stylised aesthetic that favours bold colours and bolder lines. Suggestive subject matter is a Chanhoi signature
column11: regardless of whether she is delving into the disposable nature of contemporary dating or discussing whether we can disassociate body parts from sexual content
column12: and it frequently brings her into censors' line of fire. 'My work used to be censored and taken down from social media a lot because I often feature genitals in my art
column13: ' Chanhoi told HKFP. 'Even though I feel it's far from explicit  my work still got censored
column14: ' she continued
column15: adding that it left her feeling 'confused' and 'a little bit attacked as a creative.' 'Why is my art shameful or offensive to others
column16: while we see sexualised images of women pretty much everywhere?' Rather than bend to the puritanical will of Behance
column17: Facebook and Instagram
column18: Chanhoi doubled down. 'This is why I have been constantly doing lots of work with genitals or work about sexualisation
column19: because to me
column20: it was a bit like a protest
column21: ' she said. Her frank approach to sex and sexual organs is also rooted in rebellion. 'I grew up in a very conservative environment
column22: because I was born Catholic and I also went to Catholic school
column23: ' Chanhoi said. 'I feel like the fact that I am so interested in talking about [sexuality] is just because I couldn't.' Born in Hong Kong
column24: Chanhoi's career as an artist took off while she was at art school in Britain. 'Everything came from my university projects
column25: ' she said
column26: which were largely focused on the sexual objectification of women. At the same time
column27: she was learning about her area of study outside of the institution. 'I feel like I was constantly seen as a foreign object in the UK
column28: ' she said
column29: adding that she has always felt safer in Hong Kong. 'People would cat call me and I would get a lot of comments on the way I look  and also being an Asian woman was  I wouldn't say a scary thing but I always felt like it was quite a dangerous body to be in.' London
column30: Chanhoi said
column31: has progressed since then. Her conservative hometown
column32: however
column33: has not. 'I feel like the world has changed a lot  in Hong Kong
column34: we are still
column35: let's say
column36: 10 years behind.' Chanhoi has worked with Swedish sex toy brand Lelo
column37: which surveyed Hongkongers' attitudes to sex and extras in 2021 and found that 52 per cent of respondents were not open to using sex toys
column38: saying they believed them to be perverted or were afraid of how their partner may react. Despite believing Hong Kong to be buttoned up
column39: Chanhoi said she was 'still quite surprised' to discover how many people held that opinion. 'In 2022  we see sexualised images all the time but when it comes to exploring our sexuality we're just so
column41: scared of it or ashamed of it
column42: ' Chanhoi said. 'Like it's taboo to talk about it – which it shouldn't be – because we see 'sex sells' everywhere. I just don't understand where that perspective comes from.' 'We're not supposed to be born with shame.' Chanhoi said she believed it was learned behaviour
column43: perhaps from being told not to talk about our genitals as children or being encouraged to address sexual organs by alternative names. 'But then you begin to learn that there's something wrong with them
column45: ' she said. 'This is how we learn that  some of our body parts can be shameful.' Chanhoi explores and subverts this sense of shame in her work
column46: which puts genitals front and centre
column47: always in a playful way. In one diptych pinned to the top of her Instagram page
column48: a cartoonish clitoris appears alongside a pair of testes
column49: a pubic area complete with pubic hair
column50: an Adam's apple and hairy legs. In the caption
column51: she asks: 'Can we start (de)sexualising [body parts] and look at them without shame and disgust?' Although allowed to remain on Instagram
column52: the images were recently removed from Adobe's portfolio style platform Behance. 'They just said something like
column55: her detached tone revealing how familiar she is with this response. 'You know
column56: obviously  But there's no nudity. This is what my art is all about
column58: playing around with [that] idea.' 'I am used to being censored so I like to add a little something to see if that will be censored.' On a more serious note
column60: Chanhoi said she believed something was amiss in the way we see – or rather do not see – our sexual organs portrayed in the media. 'We can't really separate sexualisation and body parts. Because we associate them with something like porn
column61: but it is not always like that
column62: ' she said. 'Lots of Instagrammers post pictures of them being super sexy and super sexualised
column63: but once a genital is featured
column66: that's so unacceptable we should take it down or remove it'
column67: ' Chanhoi continued. 'It's just really interesting that one tiny little genital could change so much when we pretty much see soft porn everywhere in the media
column68: or TV shows.' After four years overseas
column69: Chanhoi returned to Hong Kong – a city which
column71: was slow to catch on to her provocative style. 'I felt
column73: people would not be happy with my work
column74: especially in a place like Hong Kong
column75: ' she said. But 'that completely changed because of Apple Daily
column77: the pro democracy tabloid – which has since been forced to shutter after top executives were arrested under Hong Kong's national security law and its newsroom was raided by police – interviewed her. That interview 'changed the game completely
column81: I was not really an Apple Daily reader
column82: but it was so sad to see it shut down like that.' Overnight
column83: Chanhoi said she started being approached by Hong Kong based clients
column85: Hong Kong based followers. Chanhoi left her job as a brand design manager earlier this year to dedicate herself to her art full time. Still
column87: she often hears that her work is 'a bit too much' or brands will ask her to 'not include the genitals
column88: ' while saying 'we still want you to draw something about sexuality.' Most often
column89: the clients expressing such hesitations were those in Hong Kong
column91: adding that most of her commissions came from overseas. 'It's just a little bit more conservative here when it comes to sexuality and body parts.' 'In Hong Kong
column92: being an artist can be quite difficult
column94: adding that she did not see Beijing's plan to position the city as a cultural hub helping emerging artists such as herself. 'Not personally and not professionally
column95: ' she answered when asked whether the opening of M+ and other planned museums might have a trickle down effect on the local art ecosystem. Regardless
column96: Chanhoi is keeping busy. She will be speaking on genitals and taboos at the TEDxTinHauWomen event next month and has recently completed a 'really fun' project for a UK based client on the theme of sex and Christmas. 'Cute
column97: sexy illustrations  like a reindeer with a gag
column98: ' she said. Support HKFP    Code of Ethics    Error/typo?    Contact Us  Newsletter   Transparency & Annual Report Support press freedom & help us surpass 1

column2: impartial
column3: non profit The unofficial anthem of the 2019 Hong Kong pro democracy protest movement was played instead of China's national anthem at South Korea's Rugby 7s on Sunday
column4: prompting the Hong Kong government to demand a 'full investigation.' Update: National security police should investigate anthem error at rugby match
column5: lawmakers say 'Glory to Hong Kong' was heard around the stadium in Incheon
column6: during the men's final between Hong Kong and South Korea
column7: rather than 'March of the Volunteers' – the anthem the city shares with China. 'The National Anthem is a symbol of our country. The organiser of the tournament has a duty to ensure that the National Anthem receives the respect it warranted
column8: ' a government spokesman said in a Monday press release. They added: '[W]e have already written to the Hong Kong Rugby Union last evening demanding them to deal with this matter seriously
column9: launch a full and in depth investigation and submit a detailed report
column10: and convey our strong objection to Asia Rugby
column11: who is the organiser of the Series.' According to the government
column12: Asia Rugby has already apologised
column13: saying a junior staffer made a mistake and the Hong Kong team had provided the correct anthem. When 'Glory to Hong Kong' was played
column14: the Hong Kong team sought to raise the alarm
column15: and – later – organisers made a public announcement to apologise. During the prize presentation ceremony
column16: the correct anthem was played. Footage was widely circulated online overnight
column17: with the Hong Kong team appearing stone faced as the song was broadcast. Asia Rugby appears to have removed its live stream of the event. The government said the song was 'closely associated with violent protests and the 'independence' movement in 2019.' Though the protests attracted a handful of pro independence activists

column20: saying: 'The national anthem is a symbol of the country

column22: China in international games and competitions shall fully reflect this spirit to preserve the dignity of the national anthem.' Meanwhile
column23: the Hong Kong Rugby Union said in a statement: 'The HKRU expressed its extreme dissatisfaction at this occurrence and has received a full explanation of the circumstances that led to this. Whilst we accept this was a case of human error it was nevertheless not acceptable.' The authorities have refused to say if the song is illegal
column24: though it is banned in schools and police have intervened when it is played in public. Protests erupted in June 2019 over a since axed extradition bill. They escalated into sometimes violent displays of dissent against police behaviour
column25: amid calls for democracy and anger over Beijing's encroachment. Demonstrators demanded an independent probe into the police conduct

column27: which criminalises insults to 'March of the Volunteers

column1: https://hongkongfp.com/2022/11/14/expert-suggests-fewer-covid-tests-on-arrival-hong-kong-health-chief-says-current-system-to-remain/;2022-11-14 14:09:00+08:00;" Expert suggests fewer Covid tests on arrival; Hong Kong health chief says current system to remain"; Hong Kong Free Press HKFP Hong Kong news – Independent
column2: impartial
column3: non profit Hong Kong's compulsory nucleic acid tests upon arrival could be carried out less frequently
column4: a government Covid 19 advisor has said. However
column5: the city's health chief said testing requirements are to remain 'at the current stage
column6: ' adding that self administered rapid tests are less effective in catching positive cases at the border. Visitors to Hong Kong must fill in a government health declaration form and show a negative rapid test in order to board a flight. Travellers must perform daily rapid tests and four Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) tests during their first week in the city as part of a 'self monitoring' period. The PCR tests are conducted on the day of arrival – day zero – and again on day two
column7: day four and day six. If any tests return positive results
column8: the visitor will be served with an isolation order. Depending on their living circumstances
column9: they may be forced to go to a government quarantine camp. column2: can visit museums
column3: 'designated' eateries; Hong Kong Free Press HKFP Hong Kong news – Independent
column4: impartial
column5: non profit Hong Kong will soon exempt travellers in tour groups from Covid 19 rules that bar new arrivals from going to restaurants and other venues during the first three days of their visit. The government said in a statement on Monday that the new measures were announced 'under the principle of striking a balance between epidemic risks and the need for economic development.'Individuals
column6: and those not in group tours
column7: will still be subject to the usual rules. No timeline was given for the relaxation
column8: but the government said the arrangements will be launched 'this month.' Currently
column9: all inbound travellers to Hong Kong are assigned an amber code in their Vaccine Pass app for the first three days. This means they are not allowed to enter venues operating under the Vaccine Pass scheme
column10: including restaurants
column11: bars
column12: gyms
column13: salons and other businesses. Under the new arrangements
column14: those entering Hong Kong in tour groups operated by 'licensed tourist guides' will be able to enter 'designated tourist attractions' including theme parks
column15: museums and temples with an amber code in their Vaccine Pass. They will also be able to eat in the 'partitioned areas' of 'designated catering premises' that meet the government's requirements. The tour groups' travel agents must pre register trip itineraries with the Travel Industry Council
column16: a group that regulates travel agents in Hong Kong. Authorities said they are also exploring the possibility of reducing the number of Covid 19 tests tour group travellers have to undergo fewer Covid 19 tests upon arrival. At the moment
column17: arrivals must take four PCR tests – including one at the Hong Kong airport – and rapid tests every day for a week. While Hong Kong has dropped many of its strictest travel related Covid 19 measures in recent months
column18: including a requirement for arrivals to quarantine in a hotel
column19: the city still maintains rules that countries around the world have long abandoned. Businesses have expressed concern that the current '0+3' requirement is not enough to drive tourism as travellers cannot eat out and go to many attractions in their first three days. The government said plans to relax rules for travellers coming in with tour groups would move Hong Kong towards resuming normalcy and restarting tourism. 'The relevant arrangements can support the gradual resumption of the inbound travel market in an orderly manner
column20: and provide a more favourable business environment for the travel trade
column21: ' authorities said in the statement. According to the government's Covid 19 dashboard
column22: the city has seen 1.95 million cases and 10

column1: https://edition.cnn.com//2022/10/20/uk/manchester-chinese-consulate-hong-kong-protester-intl-hnk/index.html;2022-10-21 02:35:00; Chinese diplomat says pulling hair of Hong Kong protester was his 'duty'; A Chinese diplomat who was filmed pulling the hair of a Hong Kong pro democracy protester on the grounds of his consulate in Manchester
column2: England
column3: has defended his actions – saying it was his 'duty' to maintain China's dignity. 'Any diplomat' would have done the same
column4: Chinese Consul General Zheng Xiyuan said on Wednesday when asked about video footage that has emerged of a group of men assaulting the protester. The confrontation took place on Sunday
column5: when a group of pro democracy protesters turned up to the consulate with banners featuring satirical images of Chinese leader Xi Jinping. The demonstration coincided with the start of a key week long meeting of the Chinese Communist Party elites in Beijing
column6: at which Xi is widely expected to secure a norm breaking third term as leader. Video footage shows one of the pro democracy protesters – since identified as Bob Chan – being dragged through the gate into the consulate grounds and being beaten by the group of men. It also shows Manchester police entering the consulate grounds to break up the violence. In an interview with Sky News on Wednesday
column7: Zheng defended his actions and those of his staff
column8: claiming the pro democracy protesters had incited the violence with 'rude banners.' 'I didn't beat anybody. I didn't let my people beat anybody. The fact is
column9: the so called protesters beat my people
column10: ' Zheng said. However
column11: when the Sky News interviewer asked about an image showing him pulling Chan's hair
column12: Zheng seemed to concede he had been involved
column13: saying: 'Yeah
column14: the man abused my country
column15: my leader. I think it's my duty.' 'To pull his hair?' the interviewer asked – to which Zheng responded
column16: 'Yeah!' He added that he was maintaining the dignity of China and its people
column17: and that 'any diplomat' would have done the same in such a situation. In a letter to Manchester police on Thursday
column18: Zheng insisted the consulate had been 'respectful of the right to protest
column19: ' and claimed that the consular grounds had been 'stormed' by protesters. China's Foreign Ministry has been quick to defend Zheng
column20: describing the protesters as 'harassers' who had illegally entered the Chinese consulate
column21: 'endangering the security of Chinese diplomatic premises.' The incident now threatens to further damage UK China relations
column22: which have soured in recent years with disagreements over Hong Kong
column23: a former British colony
column24: a major point of contention. On Tuesday
column25: Britain's foreign secretary summoned China's second most senior diplomat in the UK
column26: Charge D'Affaires Yang Xiaoguang
column27: to demand an explanation and express deep concern at the incident. Manchester police have launched an investigation into the assault
column28: but said on Wednesday that there had been no arrests so far
column29: calling it a 'complex and sensitive inquiry' that will take time. Speaking publicly at a news conference Wednesday
column30: Bob Chan said he now feared for his safety
column31: and that of his family – echoing fears voiced by other members of Britain's Hong Kong diaspora. He claimed he had been trying to stop consular staff from ripping down protest banners when they began to assault him. 'I held onto the gate where I was kicked and punched. I could not hold on for long and was eventually pulled into the grounds of the consulate
column32: ' Chan said. 'My hair was pulled and I felt punches and kicks from several men
column33: ' he said
column34: adding the assault did not stop until a police officer pulled him back out through the consulate gate. He showed photos of his injuries
column35: saying he had bruises on his head
column37: back and around his eye. 'I fear I may be silenced by the powers that be. I fear for the safety of my family
column38: ' he continued. 'I'm shocked because I never thought something like this could happen in the UK.' Britain is home to a large number of Hong Kongers
column39: many of whom left the city after Beijing introduced a sweeping national security law in 2020. Under the law
column40: protesters and activists have been jailed
column42: civic society dismantled and formal political opposition effectively wiped out. Hong Kong leaders have repeatedly claimed that the city's freedoms remain intact
column43: and that the law has restored order and stability after massive pro democracy protests in 2019. But the combination of China's tightening grip on the city and its stringent Covid 19 restrictions have prompted an exodus from the city in recent years. In August
column44: Hong Kong logged its biggest population drop since official records began in 1961. As the size of the Hong Kong diaspora has grown
column45: and Beijing has become more assertive on the world stage
column46: the UK China relationship has also deteriorated – with British public sentiment souring as well
column47: experts say. 'The Manchester incident reflected the hardening of UK attitudes toward China since the 2019 protests in Hong Kong and the resultant cooling of UK China relations
column49: a senior lecturer in international history at the University of London
column50: adding that it partly reflected 'the intensified ideological clash between China and the West.' And it has become a bipartisan issue
column51: with members of both Britain's Conservative and Labour parties supporting 'a hard line approach to China
column52: ' he said. In remarks to the UK's House of Commons on Tuesday
column53: Conservative lawmaker Alicia Kearns called the incident 'a chilling escalation
column54: ' a sentiment echoed by Labour lawmaker Afzal Khan
column56: intimidating tactics of the Chinese Communist Party have no place on the streets of my city or my country.' 'The British government   is under pressure to do something concerning China
column57: and to stand up for Hong Kong
column58: ' Mark said – though he added that those authorities are now in the difficult position of having to 'strike a balance between confrontation and engagement with China.' © 2022 Cable News Network. column1: https://edition.cnn.com//2022/10/20/investing/china-party-congress-ny-hk-chinese-stocks-tumble-intl-hnk/index.html;2022-10-20 02:16:00; Chinese stocks tumble to multi year lows in New York and Hong Kong amid party congress;" Markets Fear & Greed Index Latest Market News Chinese stocks have hit multi year lows in New York and Hong Kong amid growing concerns about China's rising Covid cases and economic outlook. The plunge comes at a time when members of China's ruling Communist Party are meeting for the 20th Party Congress
column2: a major leadership reshuffle that sets the tone for policy for the coming years. In Hong Kong
column3: the benchmark Hang Seng

column1: (HSI) Index tumbled as much as 3% in Thursday's morning trade. By early afternoon
column2: it pared losses to 1.1%
column3: on track to hit its lowest close since October 2011
column4: according to Refinitiv. The fall comes just a day after the city's leader
column5: Chief Executive John Lee
column6: promised to invest billions of dollars to bring global talent and businesses back to Hong Kong. The index was mainly dragged down by Chinese technology companies. Alibaba

column1: (BABA)'s Hong Kong listed shares fell nearly 3%. Tencent
(TCEHY) also lost 2.9%. Baidu
(BIDU) sank more than 7%. The heavy decline followed a sharp sell off in Chinese stocks listed on Wall Street overnight. Xi Jinping's speech: yes to zero Covid
column2: no to market reforms? The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index slid 7.1% on Wednesday to close at its lowest level since July 2013. JD.com

column1: (JD) lost 7.7%. Alibaba's New York traded stock dropped 6.6%. US stocks closed lower on Wednesday
column2: with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.3%. The S&P 500 was down 0.6%
column3: and the Nasdaq slid 0.9%. Other Asian markets also fell on Thursday. Japan's nikkei 22

column1: (N225)5 dropped 0.9%
column2: while the Japanese yen hit a fresh 32 year low against the dollar. South Korea's Kospi fell 0.8%. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 lost 1.1%. But China's Shanghai Composite Index reversed earlier losses and edged up 0.3%. Analysts are concerned about China's growth outlook after Xi Jinping's opening speech at the 20th party congress. The Chinese leader offered no signs of moving away from the country's rigid zero Covid policy or its tight regulatory stance on various businesses
column3: both of which have hampered growth in the world's second largest economy. Xi is expected to secure an unprecedented third term in power at the week long congress. 'China's National Party Congress failed to drive a positive catalyst
column4: ' said Yeap Jun Rong
column5: a market strategist for IG Group
column6: on Thursday. He added that investors are also concerned that rising Covid cases in Beijing may lead to 'aggressive restriction measures.' China's capital detected 41 Covid cases on Tuesday
column7: the most in four months
column8: according to the city's health commission. The country delayed the released of its third quarter GDP data on Tuesday
column9: which has stoked further worries. 'China's decision to delay the release of key economic readings could suggest the data is so ugly that they don't want it released during the party's congress
column10: ' said Edward Moya

column2: Hong Kong plans $3.8 billion 'trawl' for global talent;" Markets Fear & Greed Index Latest Market News Hong Kong wants international firms to know it means business. The city's leader
column3: Chief Executive John Lee
column4: announced Wednesday that the government would earmark 30 billion Hong Kong dollars ($3.8 billion) for a new fund aimed at bringing more businesses in. The fund will seek to attract companies to set up operations in Hong Kong
column5: as well as invest in their businesses
column6: he said in a wide ranging policy address. The move comes after the city witnessed a massive exodus amid some of the world's strictest pandemic controls
column7: which were recently eased after more than two years. In August
column8: Hong Kong logged its biggest population drop since officials began keeping track of such figures in 1961. Lee addressed the record decline on Wednesday
column9: noting: 'Over the past two years
column10: the local workforce shrank by about 140
column11: 000.' 'Apart from actively nurturing and retaining local talents
column12: the government will proactively trawl the world for talents
column13: ' the chief executive added. Lee also announced Wednesday the launch of an initiative aimed at attracting more workers
column14: including select high earners and graduates from the world's top 100 universities. Eligible candidates 'will be issued a two year pass for exploring opportunities in Hong Kong
column15: ' he said. That should come as welcome relief for businesses in Hong Kong
column16: which had long warned of a brain drain. Before the recent removal of quarantine measures
column17: many workers had expressed frustration over the city's onerous travel restrictions
column18: which at one point required up to 21 days of hotel quarantine. The measures damaged the city's economy
column19: and led many multinational companies and expatriates to shift — or consider moving — elsewhere. Hong Kong is the Asian base for many multinational companies
column20: including top banks and financial firms. The former British colony has traditionally been seen as a friendly international gateway to mainland China. In recent years
column21: its reputation for openness and ease of doing business have fallen
column22: while rival hub Singapore raced ahead. Hong Kong is working to change that perception
column23: by stepping up efforts to rebuild its status as a global business and financial hub. Next month
column24: the city's officials will welcome some of Wall Street's top executives for a long awaited financial summit. Goldman Sachs

column1: https://edition.cnn.com//2022/10/17/uk/manchester-chinese-consulate-protesters-intl-hnk/index.html;2022-10-18 05:00:00; Hong Kong protester allegedly beaten at Chinese consulate in UK; Police in Manchester have launched an investigation after a Hong Kong pro democracy protester was allegedly beaten on the grounds of the Chinese consulate in the English city. A pro democracy group called Hong Kong Indigenous Defence Force had staged a protest outside the consulate in the northern city on Sunday
column2: in opposition to the Chinese Communist Party Congress happening the same day in Beijing. Video of the incident shared widely on social media shows a confrontation breaking out on the sidewalk outside the consulate
column3: with loud shouts heard as people rush towards the gated entrance. The video then appears to show one Hong Kong protester being dragged through the gate into the consulate grounds and beaten by a group of men. The video appears to show local police entering the grounds of the consulate to break up the violence. Hong Kong Indigenous Defence Force alleges that Chinese consular staff were involved in the alleged beating
column4: and that the protester was taken to hospital in stable condition. Greater Manchester Police said Monday they were investigating the incident
column5: in which a man 'suffered several physical injuries.' 'We understand the shock and concern that this incident will have caused not just locally
column6: but for those much further afield who may have connections with our communities here in Greater Manchester
column7: ' assistant chief constable Rob Potts said in a statement. 'Shortly before 4 p.m. a small group of men came out of the building and a man was dragged into the Consulate grounds and assaulted. Due to our fears for the safety of the man
column8: officers intervened and removed the victim from the Consulate grounds.' 'The man – aged in his 30s – suffered several physical injuries and remained in hospital overnight for treatment. He is continuing to receive our support for his welfare.' The statemented added that currently 'no arrests have been made' and that the investigation was ongoing. A spokesperson for British Prime Minister Liz Truss described the incident as 'deeply concerning.' On Monday
column9: Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin said he was 'not aware of the situation.' 'Chinese Embassy and consulates in the UK have always abided by the laws of the countries where they are stationed
column10: ' he said in a regular news briefing. 'We also hope that the British side
column11: in accordance with the provisions of the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations
column12: will facilitate the normal performance of the duties of the Chinese Embassy and consulates in the UK.' CNN approached the Chinese Embassy in London for comment but did not receive an immediate response. Video of the scuffle has been shared online by multiple UK lawmakers
column13: who have called for an investigation into the alleged involvement of Chinese consular staff. 'The UK Government must demand a full apology from the Chinese Ambassador to the UK and demand those responsible are sent home to China
column14: ' ruling Conservative Party lawmaker Iain Duncan Smith wrote on Twitter. Conservative Party member of Parliament Alicia Kearns also tweeted on Sunday that authorities 'need to urgently investigate
column15: ' and that the Chinese Ambassador should be summoned. 'If any official has beaten protesters
column16: they must be expelled or prosecuted
column17: ' she wrote. Both lawmakers have previously been vocal critics of the Chinese Communist Party. Prominent Hong Kong activists have also spoken out. Nathan Law
column18: a former lawmaker and pro democracy figure who fled to the UK in 2020
column19: tweeted: 'If the consulate staff responsible are not held accountable
column20: Hong Kongers would live in fear of being kidnapped and persecuted.' He urged the British government to 'investigate and protect our community and people in the UK.' Britain is home to large numbers of Hong Kong citizens
column21: many of whom left the territory following the introduction of a sweeping national security law in 2020 that critics say stripped the former British colony of its autonomy and precious civil freedoms
column22: while cementing Beijing's authoritarian rule. According to an online statement by organizers of Sunday's protest
column23: around 60 demonstrators had gathered outside the Manchester consulate to protest 'the re election of Xi Jinping.' The Chinese Communist Party Congress
column24: a twice a decade leadership reshuffle and meeting of the party's top officials
column25: kicked off on Sunday. Chinese leader Xi
column26: who came to power in 2012
column27: is widely expected to break with convention and take on a third term
column28: paving the way for lifelong rule. © 2022 Cable News Network. A Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All Rights Reserved.CNN Sans ™ & © 2016 Cable News Network.;CNN
